4222.44.text: was telling about all the problems

4224.47.text: of providers who were less than ethical, in his opinion,

4228.92.text: of providing back surgeries, so the question is,

4232.70.text: how do I, is the AMA, or how would you get

4236.51.text: the AMA to be more efficient, or from state to state,

4242.29.text: state to state and get relicensed.

4244.16.text: - Yeah, there are things that the insurers and the doctors

4247.84.text: agree on, and there are some that they don't, right?

4250.91.text: The insurance associations and the AMA.

4253.32.text: I think one of the things that we don't necessarily see

4256.79.text: eye to eye on are some of these payment reforms

4259.98.text: that I'm talking about, and some of them are gonna solve,

4263.19.text: help solve, the problems that you're talking about.

4265.83.text: And I would certainly not, you didn't do this either,

4268.60.text: but I would not suggest or want you to think

4270.98.text: that I'm suggesting that this is a rampant problem

4274.12.text: throughout the system, but there is fraud

4276.61.text: within the system, in South Florida, in particular,

4284.98.text: You do have, ah, a small number of physicians

4291.22.text: who are able to continue, which I think you're getting at,

4294.96.text: to survive in practice in the system by changing venues

4299.00.text: and changing states, if there's been fraud involved,

4302.61.text: but also if there's been medical malpractice involved.

4306.61.text: And that's a huge driver in costs, is medical malpractice.

4311.41.text: So, the AMA, you know, playing a role in identifying

4314.56.text: and weeding out of the profession people who fit

4317.39.text: that description, which I do think is a smaller number.

4322.72.text: doesn't do a whole lot about.

4332.00.text: and it's gonna address part of that.

4333.77.text: But look, there are rules and there are people

4341.48.text: And I think that the profession itself,

4343.73.text: the AMA in this case, is gonna be the one

4356.85.text: I was afraid of this question, coming up,

4360.72.text: - [Man In Audience] Thank you for coming.

4361.72.text: How does the big pharma play into this,

4364.14.text: as far as new drugs coming out and having really long

4367.52.text: patent process, where how do we balance

4370.52.text: their right to make money and our right

4372.96.text: to get these drugs to the patients,

4374.92.text: in the formularies and the different healthcare?

4377.78.text: - This was a huge issue, when I was in the Congress.

4381.47.text: The length of patents, and it's a big issue

4383.84.text: in California, again, you all are doing more

4387.57.text: So, 20 years in the pipeline, and so the cost

4391.87.text: of prescription drugs, the question I get asked a lot

4394.65.text: is the merits of policy to cap the price

4398.88.text: of prescription drugs, because if you look,

4400.42.text: just Google the rising healthcare costs

4403.88.text: by sector in the healthcare industry.

4406.53.text: And what you will find is almost every other sector

4410.36.text: in healthcare costs, adjusted for inflation,

4412.79.text: have remained pretty stable over time.

4415.74.text: And then you get to the pharmaceutical industry,

4420.45.text: It literally is off the charts.

4426.47.text: And it's because of some of these medical innovations

4429.20.text: that I told you about, and when you have drugs

4431.85.text: that are working and that people want to have,

4435.68.text: and there's a market for them, because they're saving lives

4439.40.text: or maintaining diseases in a way

4441.28.text: that we weren't able to do before,

4443.36.text: there's gonna be a market for that.

4444.71.text: So the issue is the pricing of that,

4446.58.text: and what that does to other insured people.

4449.95.text: So the pharmaceutical companies will argue

4452.69.text: that because almost every other country

4454.40.text: in the world has global budgets,

4456.07.text: they cap the price of drugs, that that restricts

4459.33.text: the research and therefore the R&D doesn't get done,

4462.51.text: because the one drug that turns out to be

4465.59.text: the one I just talked about, where you have

4467.66.text: a hepatitis C drug that's a thousand dollars a pill,

4471.78.text: and you take it and it works

4473.58.text: and it can eliminate the hepatitis, that's miraculous.

4478.87.text: And that's a benefit to the system.

4480.42.text: But that was years in the making, of R&D, of trial

4484.05.text: and error and failure, and eventually they got there.

4486.56.text: And the insurance, or the pharmaceutical companies

4489.81.text: will say, well, the nine out of ten times

4492.36.text: that we do that, that we're unsuccessful,

4495.79.text: that it's a dead end, we need to keep trying that.

4499.28.text: And if you lock down, if you limit the patent process,

4502.48.text: we can't recover, on the other end, the billions

4506.18.text: of dollars in costs of the R&D that never succeeds.

4513.60.text: But there's also something to the price gouging argument,

4517.20.text: where if you have something that nobody else has,

4519.58.text: and people need it to survive, they'll pay any price.

4523.36.text: And if the insurance company's willing to cover it,

4526.38.text: just jack the price up as high as you possibly can.

4530.91.text: So there is a huge battle in the industry now,

4533.38.text: the insurance industry and the pharmaceutical industry,

4535.52.text: and I spoke recently, in Miami, to the national conference

4540.17.text: of the pharmaceutical folks, and I challenged them.

4544.68.text: And I said, which is true: you guys are

4547.38.text: on the wrong side of this thing.

4549.47.text: You don't have the public interest at heart.

4551.52.text: And they know that at some point, Congress is gonna

4555.32.text: figure this out, and they're gonna fix the problem for them.

4559.46.text: Or at least, that is a likely outcome.

4561.82.text: Because that might be the only solution,

4563.63.text: if they don't self-police, if they don't figure out

4565.87.text: a way to not just make people pay any price.

4570.08.text: So the pharmaceutical companies have an argument.

4572.61.text: Yes, we wanna encourage R&D, we don't wanna pass policies

4577.53.text: and discover new miracles, but we also wanna have

4581.94.text: an industry that is sympathetic to the cost

4584.82.text: and the impact that it has on the shift,

4592.25.text: So there's a push and pull going on there.

4596.16.text: industry is not doing their part.

4597.92.text: They're just running full-speed down the track,

4599.74.text: and they are gonna do whatever they wanna do,

4604.52.text: I think that's the only way this is gonna happen.

4606.50.text: And they may set a cap on drug prices.

4610.09.text: I don't know if they'll set a cap on what we can spend,
